questions.text: A 16-year-old gymnast presents to the emergency department after landing awkwardly on her ankle after dismounting from the parallel bars. She reports that she felt her ankle roll inward. On physical examination, there appears to be a forward displacement of the talus. Which of the following ligaments has she most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The anterior talofibular ligament is likely to get injured in inversion injuries of the ankle, as in this case.

Lateral ankle sprains represent the most common sports-related traumatic lesions.

Anterior talo-fibular ligament:

  • Weakest ligament and therefore the most frequently torn.
  • The most common of the lateral ligaments to be injured
  • The most commonly injured ligament in the human body.
  • Injuries to the ligaments about the ankle usually result from inversion and internal rotation of the foot combined with ankle plantar flexion.
  • With complete disruption of the anterior talofibular ligament, forward displacement of the talus in the ankle mortise is present.
  • There is usually a predictable pattern of progression of injury that we see in the ankle. The first ligament to be injured is the anterior talofibular ligament, followed by the calcaneofibular ligament, and finally, the posterior talofibular ligament.

So, ligament strains of the ankle are of 3 types based on this progression

  • First-degree sprain is characterised by a partial or complete tear of the anterior talofibular ligament
  • In a second-degree sprain, both the anterior talofibular and calcaneofibular ligaments are either partially or completely torn.
  • Third-degree sprain consists of injuries to the anterior talofibular, calcaneofibular, and posterior talofibular ligaments.

Explanation of other options:

Calcaneofibular ligament (Option B): The calcaneofibular ligament is a lateral ligament that is injured less frequently than the anterior talofibular ligament. If injured, it is seen in association with anterior talofibular ligament injury.

Talonavicular ligament (Option C), Tibiocalcaneal ligament (Option D): Both are ligaments on the medial side of the ankle, which comprise the deltoid ligament. These are usually sprained or torn in abduction or eversion injuries.

choices.text: A lateral view X-ray is important for the diagnosis of fractures
Avascular necrosis of the body is a common complication
Displaced fractures require below-knee plaster only
Displaced fractures require open reduction & internal fixation

questions.text: A 26-year-old motorcyclist was brought to the ER following a high-speed accident. He complains of severe pain and swelling of the right ankle. X-ray showed a fracture of the neck of the talus. All are true about the fracture neck of the talus except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Displaced fractures of the neck talus need to be treated with open reduction and internal fixation, followed by below-knee plaster for immobilisation.

Fracture neck of the talus:

  • Results from forced dorsiflexion of the ankle.
  • Typically, this injury is sustained in an aircraft crash where the rudder bar is driven forcibly against the middle of the sole (Aviator's fracture), resulting in forced dorsiflexion of the ankle; the neck, being a weak area, gives way.
  • Blood supply to the body of the talus is often cut following fractures occurring through the neck.

Diagnosis:

  • AP, lateral & oblique views are essential (Option A ruled out)
  • A CT scan helps to identify associated injuries of the ankle & foot

Treatment:

  • Undisplaced fractures: A below-knee plaster cast for 6-8 weeks is sufficient. (Option C ruled out)
  • Displaced fracture: Open reduction & internal fixation of the fracture with screws.

Complication:

  • Avascular necrosis - The most common complication (Option B ruled out)
  • Osteoarthritis
  • Non-union.

Avascular necrosis of the talus:

  • The earliest x-ray sign of avascular necrosis of the body is an apparent increased density of the avascular segment.
  • In reality, it is the rest of the tarsus that has become slightly porotic with disuse, but the avascular portion remains unaffected & therefore looks more dense.e
  • There is a sign called Hawkin's sign, which is the appearance of a radiolucent line in the subchondral area of the talus after fracture treatment. Hawkin's sign is a good sign indicating revascularisation of the talus.

choices.text: Fracture dislocation at the tarsometatarsal joint

questions.text: A 32-year-old man complains of foot pain after falling off a ladder. On examination, there is plantar ecchymosis. What is likely the suspected injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Severe foot pain and plantar ecchymosis following a fall point to the Lisfranc fracture-dislocation, which involves the tarsometatarsal joint.

Lisfranc fracture-dislocation:

  • Injury involving the tarsometatarsal joint (Lisfranc joint).
  • Causes: RTA or severe falls.
  • Notorious for severe oedema/pain, foot compartment syndrome, dorsal pedis artery injury, and osteoarthritis.
  • Clinical features:
    • History of trauma
    • Severe foot pain and oedema,
    • Plantar ecchymosis.
  • X-ray finding: The fleck sign (tiny bone fragment between the base of the second metatarsal and the medial cuneiform) indicates a subtle injury.
  • Treatment: Open reduction and internal fixation
  • Complications:
    • Foot compartment syndrome
    • Dorsal pedis artery injury
    • Foot arthritis
    • Long-term pain
    • Altered gait.

Explanation of other options:

Intertarsal dislocation (Option B): Intertarsal dislocation involves the tarsal bones only.

Avulsion of the calcaneal tuberosity (Option C): Avulsion fractures of the calcaneal tuberosity are caused by forceful Achilles contraction. Endangers the posterior skin with displacement. These injuries necessitate urgent operative reduction and fixation to prevent skin compromise.

Fracture neck of the talus (Option D): Fracture of the neck of the talus results from forced dorsiflexion of the ankle. Typically, this injury is sustained in an aircraft crash where the rudder bar is driven forcibly against the middle of the sole (Aviator's fracture), resulting in forced dorsiflexion of the ankle; the neck, being a weak area, gives way.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the trauma bay after rolling a dune buggy. He is intoxicated, limping, and he describes right foot pain. Where is the injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has a Lisfranc fracture-dislocation with a fleck sign at the base of the second metatarsal.

This small bony fleck is in the Lisfranc space (between the base of the 1st and 2nd metatarsal) and is associated with avulsion of the Lisfranc ligament(at the base of the 2nd metatarsal).

Explanation of other options:

Cuboid (Option A): Cuboid fracture due to lateral stress injury of the foot, where the cuboid is crushed between the calcaneus/talus and the fifth metatarsal. This is called the nutcracker fracture.

Lateral cuneiform (Option B): Isolated cuneiform fractures are usually rare; injuries to the cuneiform are usually seen along with Lisfranc injuries.

Fifth metatarsal (Option C): Fracture of the base of the metatarsal is generally classified as

  • Zone 1 (Pseudo-Jones fracture): Avulsion fracture of the tuberosity, fracture line extends into the tarsometatarsal joint.
  • Zone 2 (Jones fracture): Fracture at the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction, fracture line extends into the intermetatarsal joint. Occurs in a watershed zone with high nonunion risk.
  • Zone 3 (Dancer's fracture): Stress fracture in the proximal diaphysis.

questions.text: In ankle and foot injuries, which among the following is the most commonly injured tarsal bone?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The calcaneum is the most commonly fractured tarsal bone. In 5-10% of cases fracture is bilateral.

Calcaneal fracture:

  • The most common mechanism of injury is a fall from height, often from a ladder, onto one or both heels.
  • During injuries, the calcaneum is driven up against the talus and is split or crushed. About one-fifth of these patients suffer associated injuries of the spine, pelvis or hip.
  • Calcaneal fracture is also known as 'lover's fracture'.
  • Plain X-rays done for calcaneal fracture include lateral, oblique and axial views.
  • Axial view of the calcaneum is also called Harris's view.
  • CT is the investigation of choice.e
  • With severe injuries and especially with bilateral fractures, it is essential to take x-rays of the knees, the spine and the pelvis.
  • Many cases of fractures of the calcaneum are associated with a compression fracture of a vertebral body (usually in the dorsolumbar region), fractures of the pubic rami, or an atlanto-axial injury.

questions.text: A 20-year-old tennis player complains of a sudden pain at back of ankle while playing, he recalls of a popping sensation being felt at back of heel. What can be the possible diagnosis in this player?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A sudden pain felt at the back of the heel with an associated ripping or popping sensation while playing is an indicator of Achilles tendon rupture.

Achilles tendon injury:

  • The Achilles tendon is the thickest and strongest tendon in the body and is also one of the most commonly injured tendons in the body.
  • The most common Achilles tendon injuries are-
    • Achilles tendinosis (formerly called Achilles tendonitis)
    • Achilles tendon rupture

Achilles tendon rupture:

  • A rupture of the Achilles tendon occurs when the tendon is stretched beyond its capacity.
  • A ripping or popping sensation is felt, and often heard, at the back of the heel.
  • This most commonly occurs in sports requiring an explosive push-off: squash, badminton, football, tennis, and netball.
  • The patient will often report having looked around to see who had hit them over the back of the heel, and the pain and collapse are so sudden.
  • The most common site of rupture is the “watershed”, a less vascular area of the tendon, which is 4 cm proximal to its insertion on the calcaneum.

Clinical features:

  • Plantarflexion of the foot is usually inhibited and weak
  • There is often a palpable gap at the site of rupture; bruising comes out a day or two later.
  • The calf squeeze test (Thompson's test) is diagnostic of Achilles tendon rupture: normally, with the patient prone, if the calf is squeezed, the foot will plantarflex involuntarily; if the tendon is ruptured, the foot remains still.

Achilles tendinosis (Achilles tendonitis): A condition that develops over time and is associated with degeneration of the tendon and inflammation that causes pain.

Explanation of other options:

Anterior talofibular ligament injury (Option A): The lateral collateral ligament of the ankle is a weak ligament and is often injured. It has three parts: (i) anterior talo-fibular; (ii) calcaneo-fibular in the middle; and (iii) posterior talo-fibular. An inversion force with the foot in plantar-flexion results in a sprain of the lateral ligament of the ankle. The anterior talofibular ligament is most commonly injured in such injuries.

Rupture of the deltoid ligament (Option C): The Deltoid ligament of the knee is a strong ligament on the medial side. It has a superficial (tibio-calcaneal) and a deep (tibio-talar) part. Rupture of the deltoid ligament is usually associated with either a fracture of the distal end of the fibula or tearing of the distal tibiofibular ligaments (or both). Such ruptures usually result from abduction or eversion injuries.

Tarsal tunnel syndrome (Option D): It is a compressive neuropathy of the posterior tibial nerve due to compression of the posterior tibial nerve behind and below the medial malleolus. Results in pain and sensory disturbance in the medial part of the forefoot.

questions.text: A military cadet complains of pain and swelling of the foot after weeks of marching drills. On examination, there is localised tenderness over the dorsal aspect of the foot. If a stress fracture is suspected, which is the most common site?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common site of stress fracture is the tibia, followed by the 2nd metatarsal. As the tibia is not in the options, the next best choice is the 2nd metatarsal.

March fracture:

  • The stress fractures of the second metatarsals are called the march fracture.
  • Results from long-continued or often repeated stress, particularly from prolonged walking or running.
  • Commonly seen in young adults, often a military recruit or a runner, building up training. The foot may become painful and slightly swollen after overuse.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female slipped from the stairs, causing her right foot to roll inward. She complains of pain and swelling around the ankle. On examination there is tenderness over the lateral aspect of the ankle. Injury to which of the following structures would have likely caused his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The basketball player has sustained an inversion injury to the ankle, and inversion injuries commonly involve the talofibular ligament.

Inversion injury:

  • An inversion force with the foot in plantar flexion results in the sprain of the anterior talofibular ligament of the ankle.
  • It is the most common ligament injury occurring in the body.

Eversion injury:

  • Eversion forces on the foot result in the deltoid ligament injuries.
  • On examination, there is tenderness over the medial malleolus.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of structures are antagonists to each other around the ankle joint?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Peroneus longus & anterior tibialis are antagonists to each other, as peroneus longus plantar flexes, while anterior tibialis dorsiflexes the ankle joint.
  • Peroneus brevis & posterior tibialis are antagonists to each other, as peroneus brevis everts the foot and posterior tibialis inverts the ankle joint.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with long-standing type 1 diabetes presents with redness, swelling and crepitus in his foot two weeks after a twisting injury. Elevation of the extremity reduces the hyperemia. A radiograph is shown in the Figure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The X-ray shows destruction, disorganisation and sclerosis of mid mid-tarsal joint along with loose bodies. This is a classical finding of Charcot's arthropathy. The patient being diabetic and hyperemia that regresses with elevation, etc., also points towards Charcot's joint.

Charcot's joint:

  • Charcot's joint is also called a neuropathic joint. It occurs when the pain and proprioceptive sensations of the joint are lost.
  • The presence of pain prevents us from any injury. This protective function is lost in sensory neuropathies (like diabetic neuropathy), resulting in reccurent and persistant damage to the bones of the joint resulting in its destruction.
  • The clinching point here is that, even though there is so much destruction going on, the patient will be pain-free.
  • Neuropathy has the greatest effect on diabetic foot pathology.

Explanation of other options:

Osteomyelitis (Option A): Refers to infection of bone associated with systemic symptoms like fever, malaise, and patients usually refuse to move the limb due to pain. Laboratory investigations show elevated ESR and CRP.

Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (Option B): Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is a hereditary sensory motor neuropathy. The basis of this is an abnormality of the peripheral myelin sheath protein as a result of duplication of chromosome 17.

Lisfranc fracture-dislocation (Option C): This involves tarsometatarsal fracture dislocation following trauma. The patient presents with foot pain and characteristic plantar ecchymosis.

choices.text: Walker boot immobilisation with full weight bearing for 4 weeks
Corticosteroid injection into the plantar fascia
Surgical release of 50% of the plantar fascia

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents to the physician with a 5-month history of plantar medial heel pain. She notices it immediately on getting out of bed in the morning, but the pain improves after a few steps. As the day progresses, her pain worsens. The figure shows a lateral radiograph of the affected heel. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is the classic history of plantar fasciitis, and the X-ray shows a calcaneal spur.

Plantar fasciitis:

  • The typical patient is 40-70 years of age and can point almost directly to the plantar medial heel as the source from which the pain emanates.
  • It is a degenerative process associated with micro-tears of the plantar fascia.
  • It is widely accepted that heel spurs can occur concomitantly with plantar fasciitis, but they are not the aetiology of the disorder.

Management:

  • Treatment is predominantly aimed at intrinsic toe stretching combined with Achilles stretching, as gastrocnemius contractures are often found concomitantly.
  • Night splints have also been found to help.
  • Local injection of corticosteroid into the heel pad is done in severe cases. But should be used rarely as they can cause fat atrophy and even plantar fascia rupture. (Option B ruled out)
  • If surgery is required because conservative management fails after 6-12 months, only the medial third of the plantar fascia is released so that the medial longitudinal arch is not compromised. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A patient with subtalar and tibiotalar arthritis underwent the surgery shown in below Xray.. The patient now complains of numbness on the plantar/lateral aspect of his foot, including the 4th and 5th toes. Which nerve was most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The X-ray shows a post-surgical X-ray of ankle arthrodesis with an arthrodesis nail in situ. Whenever we insert an arthrodesis nail, the entry point of insertion of the nail is close to the course of the lateral plantar nerve. Hence, it is at risk during this procedure.

  • The lateral plantar nerve innervates the plantar skin covering the lateral half of the fourth toe and the fifth toe.
  • This nerve also provides motor innervation to many of the deep muscles in the foot.
  • Hence, if the lateral plantar nerve is injured, there will be paresthesia of the 4thand 5th

Explanation of other options:

Medial plantar nerve(Option B): The nerve provides sensation to the plantar medial aspect of the foot. Entrapment of the nerve can occur at the knot of Henry (junction of FDL and FHL tendons). The most common aetiology for medialplantar nerve entrapment is external compression from orthotic devices. Also called the jogger's foot.

Sural nerve(Option C): Entrapment of the sural nerve is rare, typically occurring only after surgical procedures, as the nerves become entrapped in scar tissue. The sural nerve is prone to injury with lateral hindfoot procedures that use a sinus tarsi approach.

Superficial Peroneal nerve (Option D): The most common complication after ankle arthroscopy is nerve injury. The superficial peroneal nerve is the most commonly injured as the anterolateral portal is established.

questions.text: The anterior drawer test of the ankle, done with the ankle in 20 degrees of plantarflexion, most effectively tests for injury or laxity of which of the following ligaments shown in Figure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The structure marked B in the figure is the anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL), which is tested by the anterior drawer test for the ankle.

  • The ATFL is the most commonly injured ligament in ankle sprains and occurs most often with the foot in slight plantar flexion.
  • Plantar flexion of the foot causes the ATFL to become parallel with the axis of the foot and become taut.
  • Acute lateral ankle ligament injuries are very common and can result in chronic instability if left untreated.
  • Stability of the lateral ankle ligaments can be assessed:
    • Anterior drawer test: Anterior pressure on the hindfoot with the ankle in plantar flexion evaluates ATFL.
    • Varus talar tilt test: Inversion of the ankle in plantar flexion evaluates the ATFL.
  • Treatment: Conservative measures include functional rehabilitation, which is the management of choice for acute and chronic injuries. Surgical intervention is best reserved for high-demand athletes.

choices.text: Thompson test, primary repair with synthetic graft augmentation
Thompson test, VY advancement with tendon transfer
Thessaly test, VY advancement with tendon transfer

questions.text: A 28-year-old male labourer suffered a left ankle injury 4 months ago at work while unloading a dolly. He complains of difficulty in walking and pain with ambulation. Physical examination shows an inability to toe walk on the left, as well as the findings demonstrated in the figure given below. What other test will be positive, and which procedure will likely give the best result in the restoration of power and function?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The symptoms and clinical findings suggest that this patient has a chronic Achilles tendon rupture and will give a positive Thompson (Simmonds) test.

  • He would most benefit from a V-Y advancement with FHL tendon transfer, given the chronicity of the injury.
  • Chronic Achilles tendon ruptures are challenging conditions for both the patient and surgeon.
  • Functional rehabilitation is effective for acute ruptures, but there seems to be little role for this in chronic cases unless medical comorbidities preclude surgery.
  • Primary repairs of chronic injuries are difficult to achieve due to scarring and tendon stump retraction.
  • Instead, local tissue augmentation, such as VY advancements, allows functional lengthening of the tendon to span this gap. Additionally, tendon transfers allow restoration of plantarflexion strength, with the FHL tendon being the most common transfer.

Explanation of other options:

Thompson test, primary repair with synthetic graft augmentation (Option A): Synthetic graft augmentation has not shown any significant benefit for Achilles ruptures. Hence is not an appropriate management in this case.

Thomas test, VY advancement (Option B): The Thomas test evaluates for hip flexion contractures.

Thessaly test, VY advancement with tendon transfer (Option D): Meniscus pathologies are assessed with the Thessaly test.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with chronic left plantar forefoot pain, exacerbated by narrow-toed shoes. She has a history of polyarthropathy. Physical examination demonstrates no palpable lesion, but pain is reproduced with forefoot squeeze. She is RF negative but ANA positive. Surgical excision of the painful lesion is performed, and frozen section pathology demonstrates perineural fibrosis without fibrinoid necrosis. These findings are consistent with which of the following diagnoses:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical and histological findings are consistent with Morton's neuroma.

A physical exam will demonstrate pain with squeezing of the metatarsals, sometimes with a painful click (Mulder's click), and pathology will characteristically show perineural fibrosis with entrapment of the interdigital nerve.

Morton's neuroma:

  • Morton's interdigital neuroma is an entrapment neuropathy that affects the common digital nerves of the lesser toes.
  • Cumulative microtrauma is considered to result from a combination of repetitive compression of the interdigital nerve between neighbouring metatarsals as well as the intermetatarsal ligament in toe-off and traction from tethering between the more fixed medial and more mobile lateral metatarsals.
  • As a result, symptoms are exacerbated by high heels and a narrow toe box.
  • Treatment initially involves metatarsal pads and a wider shoebox.
  • But most patients go on to require surgical management, consisting most commonly of transverse intermetatarsal ligament release and neurectomy.

Explanation of other options:

Neurofibromas (Option B): May similarly present in association with a peripheral nerve, but pathology will show distorted neural histology with a hypocellular, predominantly fibroblastic network of wire-like collagen and scattered myxoid regions.

Benign peripheral nerve sheath tumours (Option C): Also called the schwannomas, they may share a similar clinical presentation. However, histologically they demonstrate a characteristic encapsulated, well-circumscribed lesion with alternating areas of densely-packed palisading spindle cells (Antoni A) and hypocellular mucinous stroma with fibrillar collagen (Antoni B).

Plantar fibromatosis (Option D): Arises from the plantar fascia and would not be exacerbated by the physical exam manoeuvres described. The lesions are usually asymptomatic but may become painful. Pathology is significant for dense fibrous tissue with mature collagen and interdigitated fibrocytes.

choices.text: Ankle arthrodesis utilising the anterior approach
Total ankle arthroplasty using lateral transfibular approach

questions.text: A 46-year-old male sustained a closed subtalar dislocation 2 years ago and was treated with reduction and immobilisation. His current radiographs are shown below. An MRI was performed, demonstrating broad-based avascular necrosis of the talus. What is the most appropriate surgical management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has broad-based avascular necrosis (AVN) of the talus with tibiotalar and subtalar arthritis. A tibiotalocalcaneal (TTC) arthrodesis is the best surgical treatment indicated. A lateral approach allows direct access to the tibiotalar and subtalar joints along with local autograft.

  • Trauma is the most common aetiology for avascular necrosis, mainly fractures of the talar body or talar neck, and comprises 75% of cases.
  • The treatment options for talar AVN are varied and dependent to a certain extent on the osteonecrosis stage.
  • Early cases can be treated with core decompression, non-vascularized, or vascularized bone graft.
  • In late cases, where structural changes have occurred, treatment modalities are salvage procedures such as arthrodesis techniques.

Explanation of other options:

Tibiotalocalcaneal arthrodesis using the anterior approach (Option A): Using the anterior approach alone would not allow access to the subtalar joint for preparation.

Ankle arthrodesis utilising the anterior approach (Option B): This patient has subtalar arthritis in addition to tibiotalar arthritis; a better pain-relieving option for this patient includes an arthrodesis of the subtalar joint.

Total ankle arthroplasty using lateral transfibular approach (Option C): Given the broad-based avascular necrosis of the talus as well as the patient's age, total ankle arthroplasty is not the best option for this patient.

choices.text: Cast immobilisation and non-weight bearing for 2-4 weeks
Cast immobilisation and non-weight bearing for 6-8 weeks

questions.text: The figure below shows an MRI image of the ankle joint. What would be the most appropriate treatment modality if the structure marked in red were acutely injured, in isolation, resulting in a partial tear?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above MRI shows coronal and axial images of the ankle. The red structure is the anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL). The most appropriate treatment of an acute partial or complete ATFL injury would be physical therapy for peroneal strengthening and proprioception.

  • The anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) is the most commonly involved in low ankle sprains.
  • Partial tears of the ATFL are usually categorised as Grade I injuries, which means there is no frank ligamentous disruption and the ankle is relatively stable on examination.
  • Treatment consists of RICE (rest, ice, compression, elevation), early protected weight-bearing, and, when comfortable, physical therapy for peroneal strengthening and proprioception.
  • Anatomic reconstruction or tendon transfers may be considered if patients continue to have pain and instability despite extensive nonoperative management.

Explanation of other options:

Cast immobilisation and non-weight bearing for 2-4 weeks (Option A), Cast immobilisation and non-weight bearing for 6-8 weeks (Option B): Immobilisation with cast and non-weight bearing is not recommended. Bracing is effective during sport, but weight-bearing is recommended.

Early arthroscope exploration and repair (Option D): Early arthroscopic exploration and repair would not be warranted in an acute, isolated ATFL injury. Arthroscopy may be indicated in acute or recurrent ankle sprains caused by anterior-inferior tibiofibular ligament impingement or posteromedial impingement lesions of the ankle.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with gradually increasing pain and deformity of the medial aspect of both feet, especially the big toe. On examination, there is a bony prominence at the first metatarsophalangeal joint. Given below is the X-ray taken. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the X-ray, we can observe that the big toe is directed laterally away from the midline. This deformity is called hallux valgus.

Hallux valgus:

  • Hallux valgus is defined as the lateral deviation of the great toe with a medial deviation of the first metatarsal.
  • Pathophysiology is likely multifactorial:
    • Intrinsic factors such as genetic predisposition, ligamentous laxity, and predisposing anatomy (convex metatarsal head, pes planus).
    • Extrinsic factors - certain types of footwear (narrow toe box, high heels)
  • It is a complex valgus deformity of the first ray that can cause medial big toe pain and difficulty with shoe wear.
  • Diagnosis is made clinically with the presence of a hallux that rests in a valgus and pronated position. Radiographs of the foot are obtained to identify the severity of the disease and for surgical planning.
  • Treatment can be nonoperative with a bunion splint and shoe modifications for mild and minimally symptomatic cases. Surgical management is indicated for progressive deformity and difficulty with shoe wear.

Explanation of other options:

Freiberg's disease (Option A): Freiberg's disease is a rare foot condition characterised by infarction and fracture of the metatarsal heads.

Hallux varus (Option B): It involves the medial deviation of the great toe is most often an iatrogenic deformity secondary to overcorrection of hallux valgus.

Hallux rigidus (Option C): A common foot condition characterised by pain and loss of motion of the 1st MTP joint in adults due to degenerative arthritis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman reports painless snapping about the lateral aspect of the right hip. He denies any history of trauma. Examination reveals no limp or tenderness. Hip range of motion is full, and there is good strength. Radiographs are normal. What anatomic structure is most likely causing these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical history patient is suffering from external snapping hip syndrome, as the condition is painless, and the lateral aspect of the thigh is affected.

Snapping hip syndrome:

Snapping hip syndrome can occur in two forms:

External/lateral form:

  • Involves the iliotibial band, tensor fascia lata, or gluteus medius, which snaps over the greater trochanter.
  • More common in women with wide pelvises and prominent trochanters, and can be exacerbated by running on banked surfaces
  • Snapping may be reproduced with passive hip flexion from an adducted position.
  • The external form usually can be treated with physical therapy alone; however, Z plasty and lengthening of the involved structure have to be done in cases not improve with physiotherapy.

The internal/medial/anterior form:

  • Involve the iliopsoas tendon, acetabular labrum, subluxation of the hip, and loose bodies. (Option A, B, C ruled out)
  • Audible pop with extension and internal rotation of the hip from a flexed and externally rotated position (can be heard from across the room).
  • Diagnosed with extension and internal rotation of the hip from a flexed and externally rotated position.

choices.text: Produces symptoms similar to inguinal hernia
Results from overuse of abdominal muscles
Repair of the anterior abdominal wall is indicated only when conservative measures fail
It is characterised by anterior pelvis or groin pain

questions.text: All are true about sports hernia, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sports hernia is a misnomer and is not related to any herniation. Injury to the muscles of the abdominal wall or adductor longus produces Inguinal or pubic pain without the classic physical findings of a true inguinal hernia.

Sports hernia:

  • Common in ice hockey, soccer, and rugby, these injuries must be differentiated from subtle hernias.
  • It is called Athletic pubalgia or Gilmore's groin.
  • Injury to the muscles of the abdominal wall or adductor longus produces anterior pelvis or groin pain. (Option D ruled out)
  • It can result from acute trauma or microtrauma associated with overuse of the affected muscle. (Option C ruled out)
  • There can be inflammation of the Rectus abdominis insertion on the pubis.
  • A combination of abdominal hyperextension and thigh hyperabduction commonly occurs.
  • Treated nonoperatively for 6-8 weeks, with rest and therapy. Active strengthening of the core, abductors, and adductors is critical.
  • Repair or reinforcement of the anterior abdominal wall is indicated after conservative measures have failed and other causes have been excluded. (Option C ruled out).

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with painful swelling behind her right heel as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a Haglund deformity, which is a swelling in the posterior aspect of the heel.

Haglund deformity:

  • Haglund deformity refers to an enlarged prominence of the posterosuperior calcaneal tuberosity.
  • It is associated with retrocalcaneal bursitis.
  • Conservatively managed with NSAIDs, external padding, ice, heel-lift orthotics, and shoewear modification.
  • Operative treatment includes débridement of the inflamed retrocalcaneal bursa along with excision of the Haglund deformity when present.

Explanation of other options:

Plantar fasciitis (Option A): This is a common cause of pain in the heel. It occurs as a result of inflammation of the plantar aponeurosis at its attachment on the tuberosity of the calcaneum.

Ledderhose disease (Option C): Refers to plantar fibromatoses, characterised by firm nodules of fibroblasts and collagen that develop in the plantar fascia. The nodules and fascia become hypertrophic, producing contractures.

Bunion (Option D): It's a swelling over the medial side of the first metatarsal head and is common in older women.
